...have a lot in common.
 
 John Forbes Kerry and those who support him seem to be prone to puffery and inflated proclaimations of his voting record. The AFL-CIO claims he's sponsored 57 bills that have passed the Senate. (It doesn't say they became law.) Other sites claim he has sponsored "hundreds" of bills that have become law.
 
 In reality, he hasn't sponsored many bills...and few of them went anywhere. Of the ones that were passed, more than half had nothing to do with anything that really matters.
 
 http://www.factcheck.org/article.aspx?docID=134
 
 Summary
 John Kerry is fond of saying "I led the fight" on a lot of things -- against Arctic drilling, against Bush's Medicare prescription drug legislation, for federal grants for 100,000 new police officers, against Newt Gingrich's attempts to lessen environmental regulations.
 But reporters who cover Congress often gave others credit for the leading roles in some of those fights -- with scant mention of Kerry.
 And The Associated Press last July found that only eight laws had Kerry as their lead sponsor, five of them "ceremonial," two relating to the fishing industry, and one providing federal grants to support small businesses owned by women.
 
 
 
 
 http://forum.johnkerry.com/lofiversion/index.php/t33963.html
 
 
 http://www.freerepublic.com/focus/f-news/1061305/posts
 
 
 http://profiles.numbersusa.com/improfile.php3?DistSend=MA&VIPID=359
 
 This document is a record and analysis of all of Sen. Kerry's immigration related congressional votes, cosponsorships, and other immigration actions during his career in Congress. Immigration Profiles is the only exhaustive source for this information available in one place.
 (If you are reading this on paper, note the "Last Updated" date above. Consult the website www.NumbersUSA.com for any new or changed information, which occurs often.)
 
 View Report Card of Sen. Kerry's Immigration Actions 
 
 Career Record Source: Congressional Record
 Leans toward higher immigration, population growth, foreign labor. 
 
 
 
 
 http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sponsorship_of_legislation_by_John_Kerry
 
 Sponsorship of legislation by John Kerry
 From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia.
 John Kerry has sponsored or cosponsored hundreds of bills during his time as a Senator. Areas of concern in the bills include small business concerns, education, terrorism, veterans' and POW/MIA issues, and marine resource protection. A full list of Kerry's sponsored legislation is available on his Senate web site; (http://kerry.senate.gov/bandwidth/issues/legislation.html) see also the AFL-CIO web site (http://www.aflcio.org/issuespolitics/politics/kerry_bills.cfm) for a selected list. There have been some reports that Senator Kerry credits himself publicly with legislative initiatives which are not actually his. However, his supporters tend to argue that Kerry has a collaborative law making style, which also results in joint-sponsor legislation.
 [edit] 
 
 Sponsorship of Legislation
 During his Senate career, Kerry has been primary sponsor of the following bills (excluding resolutions and amendments sponsored). This table does not count bills which Kerry has co-sponsored.
 Session Years Bills Sponsored Signed into law
 99th 1985-86 15 0
 100th 1987-88 21 1 (http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/bdquery/D?d100:22:./temp/~bdAOxC::/bss/d100query.html)
 101st 1989-90 44 0
 102nd 1991-92 28 1
 103rd 1993-94 27 1, 2
 104th 1995-96 32 0
 105th 1997-98 19 0
 106th 1999-00 33 1
 107th 2001-02 81 1, 2, 3
 108th 2003-04 30 1
 
 
 
 
 
 
 http://www.nytimes.com/2004/02/08/politics/campaign/08KERR.html?ex=1391576400&en=d6aa52e559f5194c&ei=5007&partner=USERLAND
 
 
 His presidential ambitions were assumed almost from the day he arrived in Washington. But around the Senate Mr. Kerry is often described as aloof, patrician, a bit of a lone ranger. 
 
 
 
 
 http://answers.google.com/answers/threadview?id=404851

 Kerry is prone to "political puffery" when it comes to his legislative record and claims of having "led the right" on a number of issues.

you may be right kerry may be as full of it as most politicians. but for me it comes down to a simple observation... i've watched the present administrations actions and quite frankly i'm not impressed. i remember watching all the hype befor the president invaded iraq and thinking to myself ...well they could be right about this weapons thing so i'm just going to wait and see befor i draw a conclusion about his actions... i've drawn a conclusion, it was all based on faulty information. i'm not going to get into the debate as to wether or not it was intentional or not it's irerelevantto the point i'm going to make.and so the point... a decision was made, and if our leaders can't get to the reality of a situation it's time for them to go!! i will vote for kerry because to me he is the lesser of two evils. who knows he may be just as bad as the bush boys in this regard but we don't know that yet because he hasn't been president. he gets my vote the same as i gave bush a chanse to prove himself. bush failed. and if kerry fails i'll be forced to vote for the next " lesser of two evils "

I question your judgement. Kerry has no real recognizable convictions or standards. His goal is to please whomever is listening at the time, including our adversaries. You're merely jumping out of the frying pan into the fire.
i'm not shure which is worse " no recognizable convictions or standards " or "recognizable convictions or standards" that are just plain wrong. beware a man who never admits a mistake.

i'm not sure which is worse " no recognizable convictions or standards " or "recognizable convictions or standards" that are just plain wrong. beware a man who never admits a mistake.
Surely, I do.
 
 Bush has not claimed to be perfect. I've also not claimed to agree with everything he has done. As a matter of fact, I've disagreed with him on more than one occasion.
 
 I don't know that Kerry has admitted to any mistakes. He just changes his stance without explaination. It's hard to disagree with a man that takes both sides.
